articles.headline: U.S. Wrestles With Taliban Sanctions as Afghan Crisis Looms
articles.snippet: The Biden administration must balance maintaining pressure and letting humanitarian aid flow.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration must balance maintaining pressure and letting humanitarian aid flow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s war in Afghanistan is over, but the fight over the Taliban’s finances is only beginning.

articles.headline: Inside the Afghan Evacuation: Rogue Flights, Crowded Tents, Hope and Chaos
articles.snippet: President Biden has insisted that the evacuation of Kabul was done as efficiently as possible. But key documents obtained by The New York Times suggest otherwise.
articles.abstract: President Biden has insisted that the evacuation of Kabul was done as efficiently as possible. But key documents obtained by The New York Times suggest otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the last day of August, when President Biden called the airlift of refugees from Kabul an “extraordinary success,” senior diplomats and military officers in Doha, Qatar, emailed out a daily situation report marked “sensitive but unclassified.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Lara Jakes and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Companies Stay Quiet on Texas’ New Abortion Law
articles.snippet: Businesses that expressed opposition to restrictive voting laws are declining to take a similar stand on the abortion measure.
articles.abstract: Businesses that expressed opposition to restrictive voting laws are declining to take a similar stand on the abortion measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Texas lawmakers advanced a restrictive voting rights bill this year, American Airlines and Dell Technologies, two of the state’s biggest employers, were early and vocal critics of the effort.

articles.headline: Your Finances Took a Hit From the Pandemic. Here’s What You Do Now.
articles.snippet: Find someone wiser than you, check your credit report and taxes, and stop catastrophizing. This is how you can do it.
articles.abstract: Find someone wiser than you, check your credit report and taxes, and stop catastrophizing. This is how you can do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe you lost your job. Maybe your hours were cut. Or maybe you had to take over caregiving responsibilities. If your income fell precipitously in the last 18 months — even if things have gotten better — it’s an uncertain time.

articles.headline: Indian vs. Black: Vigilante Killings Upend a South African Town
articles.snippet: As rioting and looting swept the country, Indians in the suburb of Phoenix set up roadblocks to police their streets. Dozens of Black people passing through wound up dead.
articles.abstract: As rioting and looting swept the country, Indians in the suburb of Phoenix set up roadblocks to police their streets. Dozens of Black people passing through wound up dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, South Africa — The blows thundered down — bats, a hammer, a field hockey stick — as Njabulo Dlamini lay curled on the pavement, trying to summon the strength to move.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Zanele Mji

articles.headline: In Invoking Beau, Biden Broaches a Loss That’s Guided His Presidency
articles.snippet: Referring to Beau Biden with families of U.S. Marines killed in the Kabul airport bombing drew criticism, but the president remains haunted by memories of a son he described as “me, but without all the downsides.”
articles.abstract: Referring to Beau Biden with families of U.S. Marines killed in the Kabul airport bombing drew criticism, but the president remains haunted by memories of a son he described as “me, but without all the downsides.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the hours before Lance Cpl. Jared Schmitz, 20, was killed by a terrorist’s bomb in Afghanistan, he posed for a photograph taken by a bunkmate. In the image, the Marine’s brow was furrowed. He flashed a peace sign.

articles.headline: Crypto’s Rapid Move Into Banking Elicits Alarm in Washington
articles.snippet: The boom in companies offering cryptocurrency loans and high-yield deposit accounts is disrupting the banking industry and leaving regulators scrambling to catch up.
articles.abstract: The boom in companies offering cryptocurrency loans and high-yield deposit accounts is disrupting the banking industry and leaving regulators scrambling to catch up.
articles.lead_paragraph: BlockFi, a fast-growing financial start-up whose headquarters in Jersey City are across the Hudson River from Wall Street, aspires to be the JPMorgan Chase of cryptocurrency.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ephrat Livni

articles.headline: Covid Deaths Surge Across a Weary America as a Once-Hopeful Summer Ends
articles.snippet: Cases are starting to fall in some hard-hit Southern states, but nearly half of Americans are not fully vaccinated, allowing the Delta variant to persist.
articles.abstract: Cases are starting to fall in some hard-hit Southern states, but nearly half of Americans are not fully vaccinated, allowing the Delta variant to persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — A summer that began with plunging caseloads and real hope that the worst of Covid-19 had passed is ending with soaring death counts, full hospitals and a bitter realization that the coronavirus is going to remain a fact of American life for the foreseeable future.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: ‘Everyone Is on the List’: Fear Grips Nicaragua as It Veers to Dictatorship
articles.snippet: A crackdown on opposition by President Daniel Ortega leaves Nicaraguans to wonder: Who is next?
articles.abstract: A crackdown on opposition by President Daniel Ortega leaves Nicaraguans to wonder: Who is next?
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — The nights were the hardest.
articles.byline: By Yubelka Mendoza, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alfonso Flores Bermúdez

articles.headline: A Skeleton for Diplomacy: How a Plan to Reconcile France and Russia Collapsed
articles.snippet: The remains of a Napoleonic general who died on a Russian battlefield came home in July. But the chance for rapprochement collapsed over concerns about Moscow’s policies.
articles.abstract: The remains of a Napoleonic general who died on a Russian battlefield came home in July. But the chance for rapprochement collapsed over concerns about Moscow’s policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LE BOURGET, France — The plan, to repatriate the skeleton of a Napoleonic general who died on a Russian battlefield two centuries ago, was supposed to bring together the leaders of two nations long at odds.

articles.headline: How’s Hollywood to Plan When It Doesn’t Know Who’s Watching What?
articles.snippet: With box office numbers way down in the pandemic and streaming numbers hard to come by, the film industry is often unable to determine whether a movie is a hit or a miss.
articles.abstract: With box office numbers way down in the pandemic and streaming numbers hard to come by, the film industry is often unable to determine whether a movie is a hit or a miss.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Labor Day weekend is typically a moment for Hollywood to take a breath and assess. After the big-budget escapism of summer and before the Oscar hopefuls of fall, what signals are moviegoers sending?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: How the Texas Anti-Abortion Movement Helped Enact a Near-Complete Ban
articles.snippet: Texans are almost evenly divided on abortion, but a combination of Republican control, conservative judicial appointments and cultural shifts helped the state’s anti-abortion movement find success.
articles.abstract: Texans are almost evenly divided on abortion, but a combination of Republican control, conservative judicial appointments and cultural shifts helped the state’s anti-abortion movement find success.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHARDSON, Texas — A steady stream of women trickled into Prestonwood Pregnancy Center late last week, alone and with partners, with appointments and without. One couple held hands and whispered cheerfully; a young woman scrolled through her phone until her name was called. A wall-mounted screen in a corner cycled through a carousel of inspirational messages. “You are strong.” “Hope is stronger than fear.” “There are options.”

articles.headline: If Gawker Is Nice, Is It Still Gawker?
articles.snippet: “I’m not interested in ruining people’s lives,” says its top editor, Leah Finnegan, who once insulted a baby in a headline.
articles.abstract: “I’m not interested in ruining people’s lives,” says its top editor, Leah Finnegan, who once insulted a baby in a headline.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I started talking with Leah Finnegan, the editor of the newly restarted Gawker, I asked her whether there wouldn’t be a conflict of interest: She had been inexplicably mean to me on the internet sometime around 2013. I couldn’t recall the details but worried she’d expect a hit piece in revenge. She didn’t remember the details, either, but shared the general recollection. “I was absolutely a terrorist,” she said in a level tone, before inviting me to her walk-up apartment in Park Slope for an interview.

articles.headline: We’ll Give You a Week Off. Please Don’t Quit.
articles.snippet: “Operation Chillax”: Companies are trying to combat burnout from working remotely by offering more time off and other perks.
articles.abstract: “Operation Chillax”: Companies are trying to combat burnout from working remotely by offering more time off and other perks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amy Michelle Smith loved working in advertising. But as she did her job from her one-bedroom apartment in Toronto during the remote-work months of the pandemic — months that stretched into a year and beyond — the line separating her personal life from her professional life started to fade, and she realized she was so, so tired.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Americans Stretch Across Political Divides to Welcome Afghan Refugees
articles.snippet: “Even the most right-leaning isolationists” are coming forward to help those fleeing Afghanistan, a pastor said. A mass mobilization is underway.
articles.abstract: “Even the most right-leaning isolationists” are coming forward to help those fleeing Afghanistan, a pastor said. A mass mobilization is underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: As Migrants Surge Toward Border, Court Hands Biden a Lifeline
articles.snippet: Desperate to control the unrelenting buildup on the border, Biden administration officials turn their focus to deterring migration, dashing hopes of asylum seekers.
articles.abstract: Desperate to control the unrelenting buildup on the border, Biden administration officials turn their focus to deterring migration, dashing hopes of asylum seekers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — When the Supreme Court effectively revived a cornerstone of Trump-era migration policy late last month, it looked like a major defeat for President Biden.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe

articles.headline: The Strange Tale of the Freedom Phone, a Smartphone for Conservatives
articles.snippet: A 22-year-old Bitcoin millionaire wants Republicans to ditch their iPhones for a low-end handset that he hopes to turn into a political tool.
articles.abstract: A 22-year-old Bitcoin millionaire wants Republicans to ditch their iPhones for a low-end handset that he hopes to turn into a political tool.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a pitch tuned for a politically polarized audience. Erik Finman, a 22-year-old who called himself the world’s youngest Bitcoin millionaire, posted a video on Twitter for a new kind of smartphone that he said would liberate Americans from their “Big Tech overlords.”

articles.headline: California Bill Could Alter Amazon Labor Practices
articles.snippet: The bill would rein in production quotas at warehouses that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.
articles.abstract: The bill would rein in production quotas at warehouses that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the pandemic’s biggest economic winners is Amazon, which nearly doubled its annual profit last year to $21 billion and is on pace to far exceed that total this year.

articles.headline: From Cradle to Grave, Democrats Move to Expand Social Safety Net
articles.snippet: The $3.5 trillion social policy bill that lawmakers begin drafting this week would touch virtually every American, at every point in life, from conception to old age.
articles.abstract: The $3.5 trillion social policy bill that lawmakers begin drafting this week would touch virtually every American, at every point in life, from conception to old age.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When congressional committees meet this week to begin formally drafting Democrats’ ambitious social policy plan, they will be undertaking the most significant expansion of the nation’s safety net since the war on poverty in the 1960s, devising legislation that would touch virtually every American’s life, from conception to aged infirmity.
